ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: DARPA Grand Challenge
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Mitchell, Ken, Mitchell, I wasn t suggesting taking on the DARPA challenge as such, as Ken points out there are many facets to the problem each of which

Hi, Mitchell, Ken,

Mitchell, I wasn't suggesting taking on the DARPA challenge as such, as 
Ken points out there are many facets to the problem each of which 
require time, research and money. However I do think that if the overall 
problem is broken down into smaller problems then each in turn is doable 
- some moreso than others. You say that your model is a greatly 
simplified version of a real world task, which is true but I think that 
if you removed the simulation of motors and motor control signals from 
your model you would have something which matches what I described in my 
email as the high-level control. With a few modifications this could 
then be pluged-in to a larger system (each part developed/evolved 
largely indepently of the others) to form part of a real world solution.

The is basically the approach that has been tried with soccerbots - as 
mentioned on this group recently. With a clear breakdown of the larger 
problem and one or two of the smaller sub-problems solved I see no 
reason why an existing darpa challenge team couldn't integrate them into 
a real vehicle. To me it looks like most of the teams could use some 
help in precisly the areas where NN's would be a good solution.

One thing that does bother me though is that to be /really/ good some 
kind of adaptive (e.g. hebbian)network would be required. So if for 
example there was a partial mechanical failure the NN could adapt (as a 
human would) to controling the system with it's new dynamics - so say 
for example the engine lost power or the brakes weren't working so good 
or the part of the suspension broke, etc.

Colin.

Mitchell Timin wrote:

>Ken and Colin are thinking much bigger than I am here.
> Although my model does include the momentum and
>velocity effects that Colin mentioned, in general I am
>planning a highly simplified model, but yet one that
>simulates the most important aspects of navigation in
>a desert race.  As an aside, I might mention that
>TORCS code is available for anyone that wants a much
>more detailed vehicle and terrain simulation.
>
>In my approach the ANN receives inputs of velocity,
>and distance coordinates to any nearby obstacles and
>the goal.  The coordinates would be in the vehicle
>centered frame of reference, i.e., distance and
>azimuth.  Perhaps angular velocity is needed as well.
>All of those values are available from the physical
>model.  The ANN converts those inputs into steering
>and throttle values, which feed into the physical
>model.  These calculations are repeated with short
>time steps, perhaps 1/20 of a simulated second per
>step.  This results in a trajectory, which is then
>assigned a fitness value.  The fitness is initially
>just the distance traveled before crashing, or
>traveling in a totally wrong direction.  For vehicles
>that reach the goal, then the fitness is further
>increased according to the average speed of the
>journey.
>
>I plan to base the physical model on RARS, which I
>developed 9 years ago, and has been thouroughly
>tested.
>
>  
>
